revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2017}} {{EngvarB|date=April 2015}} {{Infobox person | name = Richard Ayoade | image = Richard Ayoade at Soho Hotel (cropped).jpg | alt = Ayoade facing the camera | caption = Ayoade in 2011 | birth_name = Richard Ellef Ayoade | birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=yes|1977|06|12}} | birth_place = [[Hammersmith]], London, England |residence = [[East Dulwich]], London, England | alma_mater = [[St Catharine's College, Cambridge]] | occupation = {{hlist|Actor|comedian|writer|director|television presenter}} | yearsactive = 2000–present | spouse = {{marriage|[[Lydia Fox (actress)|Lydia Fox]]|2007}} | children = 3<ref name="crystal">{{cite news | author = Adam White | title = The Crystal Maze 2017: everything you need to know about host Richard Ayoade | work = [[The Daily Telegraph]] | date = 23 June 2017 | url = https://www.telegraph.co.uk/tv/0/crystal-maze-2017-everything-need-know-host-richard-ayoade/| accessdate=13 July 2017}}</ref> }} '''Richard Ellef Ayoade''' ({{IPAc-en|aɪ|.|oʊ|ˈ|ɑː|d|i}}, born 12 June 1977) is a British actor, comedian, writer, director and television presenter. He is best known for his role as the socially awkward IT technician [[Maurice Moss]] in [[Channel 4]] sitcom ''[[The IT Crowd]]'' (2006–2013), for which he won the 2014 [[British Academy Television Awards|BAFTA]] for Best Male Comedy Performance. He has often worked alongside [[Noel Fielding]], [[Julian Barratt]], [[Matt Berry]], [[Matthew Holness]] and [[Rich Fulcher]].
Born in [[Hammersmith]], Ayoade served as the president of [[Footlights]] at [[St Catharine's College, Cambridge]]. Ayoade and Matthew Holness debuted their respective characters [[Dean Learner]] and [[Garth Marenghi]] at the [[Edinburgh Festival Fringe]] in 2000, bringing the characters to television with ''[[Garth Marenghi's Darkplace]]'' (2004) and ''[[Man to Man with Dean Learner]]'' (2006). Ayoade appeared in the comedy shows ''[[The Mighty Boosh (TV series)|The Mighty Boosh]]'' (2004–2007) and ''[[Nathan Barley]]'' (2005), before gaining exposure and recognition for his role in ''The IT Crowd''. After directing music videos for the [[Arctic Monkeys]], [[Vampire Weekend]], [[Yeah Yeah Yeahs]] and [[Kasabian]], Ayoade wrote and directed the comedy-drama film ''[[Submarine (2010 film)|Submarine]]'' in 2010. He co-starred in the American science fiction comedy film ''[[The Watch (2012 film)|The Watch]]'' in 2012 and his second film, the black comedy ''[[The Double (2013 film)|The Double]]'', premiered in 2013.
Ayoade has frequently appeared on panel shows, mostly prominently on ''[[The Big Fat Quiz of the Year]]'' and served as a team captain on ''[[Was It Something I Said? (TV series)|Was It Something I Said?]]'' in 2013. Ayoade presents the factual shows ''[[Gadget Man]]'' (2013–2015), its spin-off ''[[Travel Man]]'' (2015–present) and the 2017 revival of ''[[The Crystal Maze]]''. Ayoade has provided his voice to a number of animated projects, including the films ''[[The Boxtrolls]]'' (2014) and ''[[Early Man (film)|Early Man]]'' (2018), and the television shows ''[[Strange Hill High]]'' (2013–2014) and ''[[Apple & Onion]]'' (2018–present). Ayoade has written two comedic books centring around film, ''Ayoade on Ayoade: A Cinematic Odyssey'' (2014) and ''The Grip of Film'' (2017).
==Early life and education== [[File:ADC Theatre Cambridge.jpg|thumb|upright|160px|The [[ADC Theatre]] in Cambridge, the home of [[Footlights]]]] Ayoade was born in [[Hammersmith]],<ref>{{cite web|last1=Moloney|first1=Aisling|title=Who is Crystal Maze host Richard Ayoade? Highlights from The IT Crowd, Garth Marenghi’s Darkplace and more|url=http://metro.co.uk/2017/06/23/who-is-crystal-maze-host-richard-ayoade-highlights-from-the-it-crowd-garth-marenghis-darkplace-and-more-6729457/|website=[[Metro (website)|Metro]]|accessdate=19 January 2018|date=23 June 2017}}</ref> the son of a [[Nigerians|Nigerian]] father and a [[Norwegians|Norwegian]] mother.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/theticket/2011/0311/1224291811420.html | title = Moss becomes boss | date = 11 March 2011 | work = [[The Irish Times]]}}</ref> His father was an electrical engineer. The family moved to [[Ipswich|Ipswich, Suffolk]] when he was young.<ref name="barkham">{{cite news | title = I really don't think I'm cool | author = Patrick Barkham | newspaper = [[The Guardian]] | date=1 October 2008 | url = https://www.theguardian.com/culture/2008/oct/02/comedy.television | accessdate=19 October 2012}}</ref> At fifteen, Ayoade developed an interest for film "beyond ''[[Star Wars]]'' and ''[[Back to the Future]]''", and began exploring the works of [[Woody Allen]], [[Ingmar Bergman]] and [[Federico Fellini]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Gritten|first1=David|title=Richard Ayoade: Hidden depths of the bashful filmmaker|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/film/8374530/Richard-Ayoade-Hidden-depths-of-the-bashful-filmmaker.html|website=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|accessdate=7 March 2018|date=10 March 2011}}</ref>
Ayoade studied at [[St Joseph's College, Ipswich]]<ref>{{cite web|first=Pat |last=Mills|url=http://patmills.wordpress.com/tag/st-josephs-college/|title=DREDD: HE IS THE LAW! |date=5 October 2012|publisher=wordpress.com|accessdate=5 April 2014}}</ref> and later read law at [[St Catharine's College, Cambridge]] (1995–1998), where he won the Martin Steele Prize for play production<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.admin.cam.ac.uk/reporter/1997-98/weekly/5747/23.html | title = Reporter 5/8/98: St Catharine's College | date = 5 August 1998 | publisher = [[Cambridge University Reporter]]}}</ref> and was president of the amateur theatrical club [[Footlights]] from 1997 to 1998.<ref>{{cite news|title=Alumni: 1997–1998 |url=http://footlights.org/alumni-archive?name=1990-1999 |accessdate=19 October 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121015035204/http://footlights.org/alumni-archive?name=1990-1999 |archivedate=15 October 2012 }}</ref> He and Footlights vice-president [[John Oliver (comedian)|John Oliver]] wrote and performed in several productions together, appearing in both Footlights' 1997 and 1998 touring shows: ''Emotional Baggage'' and ''Between a Rock and a Hard Place'' (directed by [[Cal McCrystal]]).<ref>{{cite web|last1=Bassett|first1=Kate|title=The Footlights lose their shine|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/4714435/The-Footlights-lose-their-shine.html|website=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|accessdate=19 January 2018|date=20 June 1998}}</ref> He says that his parents would not approve of studies considered to be of the "[[Regency era]]",<ref name="Petridis"/> adding that "a non-vocational degree seemed such an outlandish indulgence".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/lifestyle/style/submarine-is-director-richard-ayoades-coming-of-age/2011/06/07/AGvFYkNH_story.html|title=''Submarine'' is director Richard Ayoade's coming of age|first=John|last=DeFore|date=10 June 2011|work=The Washington Post|accessdate=4 January 2015}}</ref> Ayoade states that his degree in law is no longer a viable "fallback" for him and that he would need to "go back to square one".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blog.thephoenix.com/BLOGS/outsidetheframe/archive/2011/06/17/interview-with-richard-ayoade-director-of-quot-submarine-quot.aspx|title=Interview with Richard Ayoade, director of ''Submarine''|first=Peter|last=Keough|date=17 June 2011|work=The Phoenix|accessdate=4 January 2015}}</ref>
==Career== ===2000–2006: Garth Marenghi shows and ''The Mighty Boosh'' === Ayoade co-wrote the stage show ''[[Garth Marenghi's Fright Knight]]'' with [[Matthew Holness]], whom he also met at the Footlights, appearing in the show with Holness at the [[Edinburgh Fringe]] in 2000 where it was nominated for a [[Perrier Award]].<ref name="Petridis">{{cite news|title=Richard Ayoade: Meet Mr Modest |url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2011/jan/15/richard-ayoade-interview |author=Alexis Petridis |work=The Guardian |date=14 January 2011|accessdate=4 January 2015}}</ref> The show saw the debut of Holness' character [[Garth Marenghi]], a fictional horror writer, and Ayoade's character [[Dean Learner]], Marenghi's publisher.<ref>{{cite web|title=Garth Marenghi uncovered|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/1513438.stm|publisher=[[BBC News]]|accessdate=19 January 2018|date=28 August 2001}}</ref> In 2001, he won the [[Perrier Comedy Award]] for co-writing and performing in ''[[Garth Marenghi's Netherhead]]'', the sequel to ''Fright Knight''.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Welikala|first1=Judith|title=Edinburgh Comedy Award winners: where are they now?|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/comedy/comedy-news/10257221/Edinburgh-Comedy-Award-winners-where-are-they-now.html|website=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|accessdate=19 January 2018|date=21 August 2013}}</ref> In 2004, Ayoade and Holness took the Marenghi character to Channel 4, creating the [[parody|spoof]] horror comedy series ''[[Garth Marenghi's Darkplace]]''. Ayoade wrote, directed and appeared in the series, which saw Marenghi and Learner star in a 1980s television drama that was never broadcast. Learner played Thornton Reed, a hospital administrator.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Adams|first1=Erik|title=Garth Marenghi's brief, hilarious reign of terror|url=https://tv.avclub.com/garth-marenghi-s-brief-hilarious-reign-of-terror-1798241550|website=[[The A.V. Club]]|accessdate=26 January 2018|date=28 October 2013}}</ref> Along with [[Matt Berry]], Ayoade directed, co-wrote and co-starred in ''[[AD/BC: A Rock Opera]]'', which parodies life-of-Christ [[rock operas]] and aired on [[BBC Three]] in December 2004.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Lougher|first1=Sharon|title=AD/BC A Rock Opera|url=http://metro.co.uk/2007/12/11/ad-bc-a-rock-opera-587471/|website=[[Metro (British newspaper)|Metro]]|accessdate=26 January 2018|date=11 December 2007}}</ref> Ayoade was also a writer on the sketch show ''[[Bruiser (TV series)|Bruiser]]'' in 2000, which starred former Footlights president [[David Mitchell (comedian)|David Mitchell]] and [[Robert Webb]], and featured Holness.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Murray|first1=Andy|title=5 actors who took a shot at directing|url=https://www.cineworld.co.uk/blog/suburbicon-george-clooney-iflr-andy-murray|publisher=[[Cineworld]]|accessdate=9 March 2018|date=31 October 2017}}</ref> Ayoade was featured in a bit-part as a reporter in the [[HBO]] television film ''[[The Life and Death of Peter Sellers]]'' (2004).<ref>{{cite web|title=The Life and Death of Peter Sellers (2004)|url=http://www.bfi.org.uk/films-tv-people/4ce2b89c05176|publisher=[[British Film Institute]]|accessdate=26 January 2018}}</ref>
After appearing in [[Julian Barratt]] and [[Noel Fielding]]'s radio series ''[[The Boosh]]'', Ayoade was part of the original cast of Barratt and Fielding's ''[[The Mighty Boosh]]'' television show. He was originally selected to play the role of dangerous villain [[List of recurring characters from The Mighty Boosh#Dixon Bainbridge|Dixon Bainbridge]]. However, by the time the radio series transferred to television he was under contract by Channel 4 and was only able to act in the pilot before leaving ''The Boosh''. The part was taken by fellow Darkplace actor and eventual ''IT Crowd'' co-star Matt Berry. He later returned in the second series in 2005, to play the part of the belligerent shaman [[List of recurring characters from The Mighty Boosh#Saboo|Saboo]].<ref name="Petridis" /> Ayoade continued his association with ''The Mighty Boosh'' in the third series, reprising his role and acting as script editor.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Sciretta|first1=Peter|title=TIFF Movie Review: Richard Ayoade’s Submarine|url=http://www.slashfilm.com/tiff-movie-review-richard-ayoades-submarine/|website=[[/Film]]|accessdate=20 January 2018|date=13 September 2010}}</ref> In 2005, he played the role of Ned Smanks in [[Chris Morris (satirist)|Chris Morris]]' and [[Charlie Brooker]]'s sitcom ''[[Nathan Barley]]''.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Harrison|first1=Andrew|title=Totally Mexico! How the Nathan Barley nightmare came true|url=https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2015/feb/10/nathan-barley-charlie-brooker-east-london-comedy|work=[[The Guardian]]|accessdate=16 June 2016|date=10 February 2015}}</ref> Ayoade's Dean Learner character was resurrected in 2006 to host a comedy chat show, ''[[Man to Man with Dean Learner]],'' on [[Channel 4]]. The different guests were played each week by Holness.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Dobbs|first1=Sarah|title=The cast of Garth Marenghi's Darkplace: 10 years on|url=http://www.denofgeek.com/tv/garth-marenghis-darkplace/29964/the-cast-of-garth-marenghis-darkplace-10-years-on|website=[[Den of Geek]]|publisher=[[Dennis Publishing]]|accessdate=26 January 2018|date=3 April 2014}}</ref> Ayoade appeared in the satirical comedy series ''[[Time Trumpet]]'' in 2006, which is set in the year 2031 and saw Ayoade and other celebrities reminiscing about the year 2007 onwards.<ref>{{cite web|author1=''Guardian'' Authors|title=Pulling to Time Trumpet – TV's most underrated shows|url=https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2016/jul/27/tvs-most-underrated-shows-pulling-top-gear-time-trumpet|website=[[The Guardian]]|date=27 July 2016}}</ref>
===2006–2010: ''The IT Crowd'', music videos and ''Submarine'' === In February 2006, Ayoade began playing the technically brilliant but socially awkward IT technician Maurice Moss in the sitcom ''[[The IT Crowd]]'' on Channel 4, appearing alongside [[Chris O'Dowd]], [[Katherine Parkinson]] and Matt Berry. The series' creator [[Graham Linehan]] wrote the part specifically for Ayoade to play.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Framke|first1=Caroline|title=The ''IT Crowd'': “Yesterday’s Jam”/“Calamity Jen”|url=https://tv.avclub.com/the-it-crowd-yesterday-s-jam-calamity-jen-1798176988|website=[[The A.V. Club]]|accessdate=26 January 2018|date=3 June 2013}}</ref> In 2008, he won the award for an outstanding actor in a television comedy series at the [[Monte-Carlo Television Festival]] for his performance.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Whelan|first1=Natalie|title=UK actors win at Golden Nymph Awards|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2008/jun/13/television2|website=[[The Guardian]]|accessdate=26 January 2018|date=13 June 2008}}</ref> In 2009, Ayoade co-starred with [[Joel McHale]] in the pilot for an American remake, reprising his role with the same appearance and personality; no series was commissioned, and the pilot never aired.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Anders|first1=Charlie Jane|title=The Failed U.S. Remake Of The ''IT Crowd'' Is Fascinating To Watch|url=https://io9.gizmodo.com/the-failed-u-s-remake-of-the-it-crowd-is-fascinating-t-1557311843|website=[[Gizmodo]]|accessdate=26 January 2018|date=2 April 2014}}</ref> ''The IT Crowd'' ran for four seasons until 2010, with a special airing in 2013, for which Ayoade won a [[British Academy Television Awards|BAFTA]] for [[British Academy Television Award for Best Male Comedy Performance|Best Male Comedy Performance]].<ref>{{cite news|first=Jess |last=Denham |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/tv/news/tv-baftas-2014-winners-list-in-full-from-broadchurch-to-southcliffe-9392993.html |title=TV Baftas 2014: Winners' list in full from Broadchurch to Southcliffe |work=The Independent |date=18 May 2014 |accessdate=22 June 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/showbiz/i684851-9/bafta-television-awards-2014-bafta-television-awards-2014-richard-ayoade.html#~oPc7r1NZMDhSzS|website=Digitalspy|title=BAFTA Television awards 2014: Richard Ayoade with the BAFTA for Male Performance in a Comedy Programme|accessdate=7 September 2014}}</ref> In 2007, Ayoade directed the music videos for the songs "[[Fluorescent Adolescent]]" by [[Arctic Monkeys]] and [[Super Furry Animals]]'s "[[Run-Away (Super Furry Animals song)|Run-Away]]", which starred Matt Berry. The former received a [[UK Music Video Awards|UK Music Video Award]] nomination, attributed by Ayoade only to the song being "so good".<ref name="barkham" /> Ayoade has frequently appeared as a panelist on the quiz show ''[[The Big Fat Quiz of the Year]]'', often with Noel Fielding, making his first appearance in ''The Big Fat Anniversary Quiz'' in 2007, which marked Channel 4's 25th anniversary.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Pearson|first1=Catherine|title=Richard Ayoade's 9 greatest TV moments|url=http://www.digitalspy.com/tv/feature/a847134/richard-ayoade-greatest-moments/|website=[[Digital Spy]]|accessdate=6 March 2018|date=10 January 2018}}</ref>
In 2008, Ayoade directed the music videos for two [[Vampire Weekend]] singles – "[[Oxford Comma (song)|Oxford Comma]]", filmed in one [[long take]],<ref name="barkham" /> and "[[Cape Cod Kwassa Kwassa]]".<ref>{{cite web|last1=Morris|first1=John|title=Search Results Vampire Weekend Looking More True To Their Name In 'Cape Cod Kwassa Kwassa'|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/1591098/vampire-weekend-looking-more-true-to-their-name-in-cape-cod-kwassa-kwassa-video-by-john-norris/|publisher=[[MTV News]]|accessdate=6 March 2018|date=17 July 2008}}</ref> In the same year, he also directed the videos for [[The Last Shadow Puppets]] songs "[[Standing Next to Me]]" and "[[My Mistakes Were Made for You]]", the latter of which was inspired by [[Federico Fellini]]'s ''[[Spirits of the Dead|Toby Dammit]]''.<ref name="barkham" /><ref name="Independent">{{cite web|title=Periscope up: Richard Ayoade and Alex Turner unite their talents in hot new Brit flick Submarine|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/films/features/periscope-up-richard-ayoade-and-alex-turner-unite-their-talents-in-hot-new-brit-flick-submarine-2243847.html|website=[[The Independent]]|accessdate=6 March 2018|date=20 March 2011}}</ref> He directed a live Arctic Monkeys DVD entitled ''[[At the Apollo]]'' (2008), which was recorded at the [[Manchester Apollo]] on [[super 16mm]] film. It was previewed at [[Vue (cinema)|Vue]] cinemas across the UK during October 2008 and was released on DVD the following month.<ref>{{cite web|title=Arctic Monkeys at the Apollo|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2008/oct/12/arcticmonkeys-popandrock|website=[[The Guardian]]|accessdate=6 March 2018|date=12 October 2008}}</ref> He was featured in [[Paul King (director)|Paul King]]'s film, ''[[Bunny and the Bull]]'' (2009), playing the role of an extremely boring museum tour guide.<ref>{{cite web | title = Made in Britain: Warp Films at 10; Bunny and the Bull | publisher =British Film Institute | url = https://whatson.bfi.org.uk/Online/default.asp?BOparam::WScontent::loadArticle::permalink=bunny-and-the-bull}}</ref> He also directed two music videos for the Arctic Monkeys – "[[Crying Lightning]]" and "[[Cornerstone (song)|Cornerstone]]" – and another for [[Kasabian]]'s "[[West Ryder Pauper Lunatic Asylum|Vlad the Impaler]]", starring Noel Fielding, and "[[Heads Will Roll (song)|Heads Will Roll]]" by [[Yeah Yeah Yeahs]].<ref name="Independent" /><ref>{{cite web|last1=Cochrane|first1=Greg|title=Kasabian ready 'psychedelic' LP|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/newsbeat/hi/music/newsid_8057000/8057717.stm|website=[[Newsbeat]]|publisher=[[BBC News]]|accessdate=6 March 2018|date=20 May 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Fullerton|first1=Jamie|title=Yeah Yeah Yeahs premiere Richard Ayoade-directed video online|url=http://www.nme.com/news/music/yeah-yeah-yeahs-68-1317106|website=[[NME]]|accessdate=6 March 2018|date=26 May 2009}}</ref>
In 2010, Ayoade made his debut directorial feature, ''[[Submarine (2010 film)|Submarine]]'', a [[Bildungsroman|coming-of-age]] comedy-drama adapted by Ayoade from the 2008 novel of the same name by [[Joe Dunthorne]]. The film stars newcomers [[Craig Roberts]] and [[Yasmin Paige]] with [[Sally Hawkins]], [[Noah Taylor]] and [[Paddy Considine]]. It follows Welsh teenager Oliver Tate (Roberts) as he becomes infatuated with a classmate (Paige) and the turmoil of his parent's failing relationship.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Scott|first1=A.O.|authorlink1=A.O. Scott|title=Coming of Age, and Then to Terms|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/06/03/movies/submarine-with-craig-roberts-review.html|website=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=6 March 2018|date=2 June 2011}}</ref> Produced by [[Warp Films]] and [[Film4]], the film premiered at the [[2010 Toronto International Film Festival|35th Toronto International Film Festival]] in September 2010 and went on general release in the UK in March 2011 and was released in June in the US after being picked up by [[the Weinstein Company]] for a North American release.<ref>{{cite news |author=Brad Frenette |title=Toronto International Film Fest announces 2010 lineup |work=[[National Post]] |date=27 July 2010 |url=http://arts.nationalpost.com/2010/07/27/happening-now-toronto-international-film-fest-announces-2010-galas/ |accessdate=19 October 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |author=Diana Lodderhose and Pamela McClintock |title=Weinsteins win 'Submarine' bidding war |work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |date=15 September 2010 |url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1118024189 |accessdate=19 October 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120209233657/http://www.variety.com/article/VR1118024189 |archivedate=9 February 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Arctic Monkeys and The Last Shadow Puppets frontman [[Alex Turner (musician)|Alex Turner]] contributed five original songs to the soundtrack, inspired by [[Simon & Garfunkel]]'s music being featured in ''[[The Graduate]]'' (1967).<ref name="Independent" /> The film was positively received by critics, with ''[[The Guardian]]'' critic [[Peter Bradshaw]] calling Ayoade a "tremendous new voice in British film".<ref>{{cite web|last1=Bradshaw|first1=Peter|title=Submarine – review|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2011/mar/17/submarine-review|website=[[The Guardian]]|accessdate=6 March 2018|date=17 March 2011}}</ref> Ayoade was nominated for a BAFTA for Outstanding Debut by a British Writer, Director or Producer at the [[65th British Academy Film Awards]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/articles/4BrzBxPM01G5pcCzgqCj5rQ/bafta-film-awards-2012-nominations|title=Bafta Film Awards 2012: Nominations|website=[[BBC Online]]|publisher=[[BBC|British Broadcasting Service]]|accessdate=16 June 2016}}</ref>
===2011–present: Mainstream cinema and television presenting === In March 2011, Ayoade directed the ''[[Community (TV series)|Community]]'' episode "[[Critical Film Studies]]" in the show's [[Community (season 2)|second season]]. The episode pays homage to the 1981 film ''[[My Dinner with Andre]]'' and was named the "most brilliant half-hour of TV to arrive in this century" by ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' writer [[Rob Sheffield]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Sheffield|first1=Rob|title=Community's "Critical Film Studies": Celebrating Two Years of the 21st Century's Greatest TV Episode|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/communitys-critical-film-studies-celebrating-two-years-of-the-2aast-century-s-greatest-tv-episode-20130329|website=[[Rolling Stone]]|accessdate=16 June 2016|date=29 March 2013}}</ref> Ayoade then directed a performance of comedian [[Tommy Tiernan]]'s world stand-up tour, ''Crooked Man'', which was released in November 2011.<ref>{{cite news | last = Sheridan | first = Colette | title = Far from Hollywood | url = http://www.irishexaminer.com/features/far-from-hollywood-172068.html | date = 28 October 2011 | accessdate = 19 October 2012 | newspaper = [[Irish Examiner]] | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120606144210/http://www.irishexaminer.com/features/far-from-hollywood-172068.html | archivedate = 6 June 2012 | df = dmy-all }}</ref> Ayoade provided his voice to the main cast of Channel 4's ill-received animated sitcom ''[[Full English (TV series)|Full English]]'', which aired for just five episodes in 2012 before being cancelled.<ref>{{cite web|title=Channel 4 shelves final episode of Full English|url=https://www.comedy.co.uk/tv/news/1004/full_english_gypsy_episode_cancelled/|publisher=[[British Comedy Guide]]|accessdate=6 March 2018|date=17 December 2012}}</ref> Ayoade starred opposite [[Ben Stiller]], [[Vince Vaughn]] and [[Jonah Hill]] in the science fiction comedy ''[[The Watch (2012 film)|The Watch]]'' as a [[neighbourhood watch]] group that uncovers alien forces threatening the world. The film was not well received by critics, although Ayoade's performance was praised. Keith Phipps of ''[[The A.V. Club]]'' felt the film's "brightest spots" came courtesy of Ayoade, while Michael Phillips of the ''[[Chicago Tribune]]'' felt Ayoade was "the reason it's not entirely lame".<ref>{{cite web|last1=Phipps|first1=Keith|title=The Watch|url=https://film.avclub.com/the-watch-1798173602|website=[[The A.V. Club]]|accessdate=6 March 2018|date=26 July 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Phillips|first1=Michael|title='The Watch': These guardians out of time, tune|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/entertainment/movies/chi-the-watch-movie-review-20120726-column.html|website=[[Chicago Tribune]]|accessdate=6 March 2018|date=26 July 2012}}</ref> Also in 2012, Ayoade began voicing Todd Lagoona, an anthropomorphic [[hammerhead shark]] who was a recurring character in ''[[Noel Fielding's Luxury Comedy]]''.<ref>{{cite web|title=Richard Ayoade joins Noel Fielding's show|url=http://www.chortle.co.uk/news/2011/07/04/13577/richard_ayoade_joins_noel_fieldings_show|publisher=[[Chortle]]|accessdate=6 March 2018|date=4 July 2011}}</ref>
[[File:John Slattery (God’s Pocket) and Richard Ayoade (The Double) (12026171294) (Cropped).png|thumb|upright|left|160px|Ayoade at the 2014 [[Sundance Film Festival]]]] From 2013 to 2014, Ayoade voiced Templeton, the class nerd, in the [[CBBC]] animated series ''[[Strange Hill High]]''.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Jeffery|first1=Morgan|title=Strange Hill High: The best kids' show on television|url=http://www.digitalspy.com/tv/feature/a593193/strange-hill-high-the-best-kids-show-on-television/|website=[[Digital Spy]]|accessdate=6 March 2018|date=28 August 2014}}</ref> Ayoade replaced [[Stephen Fry]] as presenter in the second series of Channel 4's ''[[Gadget Man]]'' in September 2013 and also presented a third and fourth season.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/tv/news/a477837/richard-ayoade-replaces-stephen-fry-on-channel-4s-gadget-man.html | first = Alex | last = Fletcher | title = Richard Ayoade replaces Stephen Fry on Channel 4's 'Gadget Man' | accessdate = 8 March 2018 | date = 1 May 2013 | work = [[Digital Spy]]}}</ref> The series featured Ayoade presenting a variety of innovative products and [[gadgets]]. He is also the host of the spin-off series ''[[Travel Man]]'', which sees Ayoade spend 48 hours in a different location each episode with a celebrity guest.<ref>{{cite news|author1=Ellen E Jones|title=Travel Man, Channel 4 – TV review |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/tv/reviews/travel-man-channel-4-tv-review-10144600.html |newspaper=[[The Independent]] |accessdate=16 June 2016|date=30 March 2015}}</ref> Ayoade was a team captain on the Channel 4 panel show ''[[Was It Something I Said? (TV series)|Was It Something I Said?]]'', which began airing October 2013 and co-starred [[David Mitchell (comedian)|David Mitchell]] as host and [[Micky Flanagan]] as fellow team captain.<ref>{{cite news | title = David Mitchell recruits Richard Ayoade and Micky Flanagan for new series | url = https://www.theguardian.com/media/mediamonkeyblog/2013/jun/06/david-mitchell-richard-ayoade-micky-flanagan | author = Media Monkey | accessdate = 8 March 2018 | date =6 June 2013| work=The Guardian |location=London}}</ref> Also in 2013, Ayoade read [[Roald Dahl]]'s children book ''[[The Twits]]'' for [[Penguin Audio]]'s [[audiobook]] collection and [[Virgin Media]] launched an advertising campaign starring the Jamaican sprinter [[Usain Bolt]], featuring the voice of Ayoade.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bookriot.com/2013/09/05/listen-kate-winslet-richard-ayoade-famous-people-read-roald-dahl/|accessdate=1 January 2015|title=Listen to Kate Winslet, Richard Ayoade and Other Famous People Read Roald Dahl|author=Rachel Smalter Hall|publisher=bookriot.com|date=5 September 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Macleod|first1=Duncan|title=Virgin Media Bolt vs Blot|url=http://theinspirationroom.com/daily/2013/virgin-media-bolt-vs-blot/|website=The Inspiration Room|accessdate=6 March 2018|date=9 July 2013}}</ref> He again lent his voice to an advertising campaign when he provided the voice-over for Apple's [[iPhone 6]] campaign with Chris O'Dowd in 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tuaw.com/2014/10/13/uk-iphone-6-ad-features-chris-odowd-and-richard-ayoade-the-it/ |accessdate=1 January 2015|title=UK iPhone ad features Chris O' Dowd and Rchard Ayoade (The IT Crowd)|author=Michael Bond |publisher=[[Engadget]] |date=13 October 2014}}</ref>
Ayoade's second feature film, the black comedy thriller ''[[The Double (2013 film)|The Double]]'', was based on [[Fyodor Dostoyevsky]]'s 1846 novella ''[[The Double (Dostoyevsky novel)|The Double]]'' and written by Ayoade and Avi Korine.<ref name="TheDouble">{{cite web|last1=Kemp|first1=Stuart|title=Jesse Eisenberg, Mia Wasikowska Join ‘The Double’ Cast|url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/jesse-eisenberg-mia-wasikowska-the-double-286385|website=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|accessdate=6 March 2018|date=1 February 2012}}</ref> It stars [[Jesse Eisenberg]] and [[Mia Wasikowska]]. The story concerns a timid man who becomes frustrated by the appearance of his charming [[doppelgänger]], both of whom are played by Eisenberg.<ref name="TheDouble" /> ''The Double'' was released in April 2014 to generally positive reviews.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Double (2014) Reviews)|url=http://www.metacritic.com/movie/the-double-2013|publisher=[[Metacritic]]|accessdate=6 March 2018}}</ref> The film drew comparisons to [[Terry Gilliam]]'s ''[[Brazil (1985 film)|Brazil]]'' (1985), both in its visuals and narrative.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Chang|first1=Justin8|title=Toronto Film Review: ‘The Double’|url=https://variety.com/2013/film/reviews/the-double-review-toronto-1200606141/|website=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|accessdate=6 March 2018|date=10 September 2013}}</ref> In the [[stop-motion]] animated fantasy film ''[[The Boxtrolls]]'' (2014), Ayoade voiced Mr. Pickles, a henchman to the film's antagonist Snatcher (voiced by [[Ben Kingsley]]).<ref>{{cite web|last1=Duralde|first1=Alonso|title=‘Boxtrolls’ Venice Review: A Charmless Misfire from Laika Studios|url=https://www.thewrap.com/boxtrolls-review-laika-animation-ben-kingsley/|website=[[The Wrap]]|accessdate=6 March 2018|date=31 August 2014}}</ref>
Ayoade's first book ''Ayoade on Ayoade: A Cinematic Odyssey'' was published by [[Faber and Faber]] on 2 October 2014. It satirises the nature of interviews and books that document and analyse the careers of iconic film directors (e.g. [[Orson Welles]] and [[Martin Scorsese]]). The book parodies Faber's ''Directors on Directors'' series, in which critically celebrated filmmakers discuss their work, and sees Ayoade conduct several interviews with himself in which he discusses his work and enthusiasm for the world of cinema.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/books/11205032/Richard-Ayoade-on-Ayoade-A-Cinematic-Odyssey-Review.html|accessdate=1 January 2015|title=Ayoade on Ayoade by Richard Ayoade, review 'a 300-page in joke'|author=Anna Leszkiewicz|work=The Daily Telegraph|date=4 November 2014}}</ref> Ayoade voiced a villainous snowman in several episodes the [[Danger Mouse (2015 TV series)|2015 reboot]] of the animated series ''[[Danger Mouse (1981 TV series)|Danger Mouse]]''.<ref>{{cite web|title=Richard Ayoade joins Danger Mouse|url=http://www.chortle.co.uk/news/2015/09/04/23171/richard_ayoade_joins_danger_mouse|publisher=[[Chortle]]|accessdate=6 March 2018|date=4 September 2015}}</ref> Ayoade directed a short music video for the [[Radiohead]] song "Tinker Tailor Soldier Sailor Rich Man Poor Man Beggar Man Thief" in June 2016, as part of a series of video vignettes to promote their album ''[[A Moon Shaped Pool]]'' (2016).<ref>{{cite web|last1=Gordon|first1=Jeremy|title=Watch Radiohead’s New Short Video Directed by Richard Ayoade|url=https://pitchfork.com/news/66173-watch-radioheads-new-short-video-directed-by-richard-ayoade/|website=[[Pitchfork (website)|Pitchfork]]|accessdate=7 March 2018|date=17 June 2016}}</ref>
In January 2017, it was announced that Ayoade would present 20 hour-long episodes of the game show ''[[The Crystal Maze]]'', following the success of a celebrity special for [[Stand Up to Cancer]] in October 2016 hosted by [[Stephen Merchant]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.com/tv/news/a818911/the-crystal-maze-return-channel-4-richard-ayoade/|title=Crystal Maze returning to Channel 4 for a FULL SERIES|date=13 January 2017|publisher=[[Digital Spy]]|accessdate=4 May 2017}}</ref> The show also features comedians [[Jessica Hynes]] and [[Adam Buxton]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Adam Buxton and Jessica Hynes join Richard Ayoade in Channel 4's Crystal Maze reboot|url=http://www.radiotimes.com/news/2017-06-12/adam-buxton-and-jessica-hynes-join-richard-ayoade-in-channel-4s-crystal-maze-reboot|website=Radio Times|accessdate=12 June 2017}}</ref> It premiered in June 2017.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Hutchinson|first1=Kate|title='Start the fans, please!' How The Crystal Maze made a comeback|url=https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2017/jun/21/how-the-crystal-maze-made-a-comeback|website=[[The Guardian]]|accessdate=7 March 2018|date=21 June 2017}}</ref> Ayoade made a [[cameo appearance]] in the comedy sequel ''[[Paddington 2]]'' as a [[forensic investigator]] and was amongst the voice cast for Vampire Weekend [[Ezra Koenig]]'s animated series ''[[Neo Yokio]]'' in the same year.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Desta|first1=Yohana|title=''Paddington 2'' Review: An Inviting, Necessary Bit of Escapism|url=https://www.vanityfair.com/hollywood/2018/01/paddington-2-review|website=[[Vanity Fair (magazine)|Vanity Fair]]|accessdate=8 March 2018|date=9 January 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Shannon Miller|first1=Liz|title=‘Neo Yokio’ Voice Cast: A Visual Guide to Who Played Whom in New Netflix Animated Series|url=http://www.indiewire.com/2017/09/neo-yokio-voice-cast-netflix-1201879584/|website=[[IndieWire]]|accessdate=7 March 2018|date=23 September 2017}}</ref> His second book, ''The Grip Of Film'', was published in October 2017. Written in the perspective of clueless film fanatic Gordy LaSure, in its canon is an A-Z of films and what makes them good with footnotes by Ayoade.<ref>{{cite web|title=Richard Ayoade writes a new cinema book|url=http://www.chortle.co.uk/news/2017/08/09/37398/richard_ayoade_writes_a_new_cinema_book|publisher=[[Chortle]]|accessdate=7 March 2018|date=9 August 2017}}</ref> He guest hosted an episode of the panel show ''[[Have I Got News for You]]'' in late 2017.<ref>{{cite web|title=Have I Got News For You|url=https://www.comedy.co.uk/tv/hignfy/episodes/54/2/|publisher=[[British Comedy Guide]]|accessdate=7 March 2018}}</ref> Ayoade starred in an advertisement for [[HSBC]] in 2018, which addressed other countries' cultural impact on the United Kingdom ahead of [[Brexit]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Williams|first1=Eliza|title=HSBC addresses Brexit in new ad|url=https://www.creativereview.co.uk/hsbc-addresses-brexit-new-ad/|website=[[Creative Review]]|accessdate=7 March 2018|date=2 January 2018}}</ref> Ayoade voiced Treebor, a [[Stone Age]] caveman, in the [[Aardman Animations]] stop-motion comedy ''[[Early Man (film)|Early Man]]'' (2018).<ref>{{cite web|last1=Ritman|first1=Alex|title=Timothy Spall, Richard Ayoade Board Aardman's 'Early Man' as Teaser Trailer Debuts|url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/timothy-spall-richard-ayoade-board-aardmans-early-man-as-teaser-trailer-debuts-986646|website=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|accessdate=7 March 2018|date=16 March 2017}}</ref> Since February 2018, Ayoade has voiced Onion, one of the title characters in the [[Cartoon Network]] animated series ''[[Apple & Onion]]''.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Thurm|first1=Eric|title=Cartoon Network's ''Apple & Onion'' isn't the freshest fruit, but it's still pretty tasty|url=https://www.avclub.com/cartoon-networks-apple-onion-isnt-the-freshest-fruit-1823192194|website=[[The A.V. Club]]|accessdate=7 March 2018|date=23 February 2018}}</ref> Ayoade will be featured in a supporting role in [[Joanna Hogg]]'s two-part romantic mystery film ''The Souvenir'' (2018), starring [[Robert Pattinson]] in the lead role.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Ford|first1=Rebecca|title=Cannes: Robert Pattinson to Star in Two-Part Film 'The Souvenir'|url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/cannes-robert-pattinson-star-two-part-film-souvenir-1005746|website=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|accessdate=7 March 2018|date=20 May 2017}}</ref>
==Influences== In an interview with [[Rotten Tomatoes]], Ayoade cited his favourite films as being ''[[Zazie dans le Métro]]'' (1960), ''[[Crimes and Misdemeanors]]'' (1989), ''[[Persona (1966 film)|Persona]]'' (1966), ''[[Days of Heaven]]'' (1978) and ''[[Taxi Driver]]'' (1976).<ref>{{cite web|last1=Goodsell|first1=Luke|title=Five Favorite Films With Submarine Director Richard Ayoade|url=https://editorial.rottentomatoes.com/article/five-favorite-films-with-submarine-director-richard-ayoade/|publisher=[[Rotten Tomatoes]]|accessdate=7 March 2018|date=1 June 2011}}</ref> Ayoade is a fan of [[French New Wave]] cinema and said in an interview with ''[[The Guardian]]'' that [[Louis Malle]]'s ''Zazie dans le Métro'' was the film that sparked his interest in filmmaking.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Holland|first1=Mina|title=The film that changed my life: Richard Ayoade|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2011/jul/31/richard-ayoade-film-changed-life|website=[[The Guardian]]|accessdate=7 March 2018|date=31 July 2011}}</ref> His favourite filmmakers include Malle, [[Woody Allen]], [[Ingmar Bergman]], [[Orson Welles]], [[Jean-Luc Godard]], [[Jean-Pierre Melville]] and [[Paul Thomas Anderson]].<ref name="crystal" /><ref>{{cite web|last1=Bowie-Sell|first1=Daisy|title=Richard Ayoade on Paul Thomas Anderson|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/film/8682288/Richard-Ayoade-on-Paul-Thomas-Anderson.html|website=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|accessdate=7 March 2018|date=4 August 2011}}</ref>
==Personal life== Ayoade married actress [[Lydia Fox (actress)|Lydia Fox]] in 2007. They have three children and reside in [[East Dulwich]] in the [[London Borough of Southwark]] in England.<ref name="crystal"/><ref>{{cite web|title=Richard Ayoade on his new film The Double|url=http://www.theresident.co.uk/london-culture-events/celeb-interviews/richard-ayoade-film-double/|website=[[Archant|The Resident]]|accessdate=7 March 2018|date=26 March 2014}}</ref>

(TV series)|Was It Something I Said?]]'' | Himself | 8 episodes |- | 2013–2014 | ''[[Strange Hill High]]'' | Templeton (voice) | 26 episodes |- | 2013–2015 | ''[[Gadget Man]]'' | Himself (host) | 19 episodes |- | 2015 | ''[[The Vicar of Dibley]]'' | Bernard | Episode: "The Bishop of Dibley" |- | 2015–2016 | ''[[Danger Mouse (2015 TV series)|Danger Mouse]]'' | The Snowman (voice) | 4 episodes |- | 2015–present | ''[[Travel Man]]'' | Himself (host) | 26 episodes |- | 2016–present |''[[8 Out of 10 Cats Does Countdown]]'' | Himself (guest contestant) | 3 episodes |- | 2017 | ''[[Neo Yokio]]'' | Various characters (voice) | 3 episodes |- | 2017–present | ''[[The Crystal Maze]]'' | Himself (host) | 21 episodes<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/newsbeat/article/38612985/the-crystal-maze-is-coming-back-with-richard-ayoade-as-host |title=The Crystal Maze is coming back with Richard Ayoade as host - BBC Newsbeat |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date=13 January 2017 |accessdate=19 April 2017}}</ref> |- | 2018 | ''[[Apple & Onion]]'' | Onion (voice) | |- | 2019 | ''[[The Moomins (2019 TV series)|Moominvalley]]'' | The Ghost (voice) | |}
